summary: This is an FBI FD-302 interview report of EDWARD BERTRAND, a former employee of the Virgin Islands Water and Power Authority (WAPA), conducted on September 9, 2021. Bertrand provides information about alleged corruption involving former WAPA officials, including their private work using public resources and specific connections to electrical work on Jeffrey Epstein's islands.

events.title: FBI Interview of Edward Bertrand
events.description: Edward Bertrand is interviewed by FBI agents and a U.S. Attorney's Office representative at the St. Thomas FBI office regarding WAPA operations and alleged corruption.

events.title: Bertrand becomes Staking Engineer
events.description: Edward Bertrand transitions from mapping power lines and water mains to becoming a Staking Engineer at WAPA, responsible for surveying new construction sites and determining electrical meter placements.

events.title: Alleged Double-Dipping Scheme
events.description: Clinton Hedrington and Felix Rey allegedly use WAPA materials, equipment, and personnel to complete private electrical contracts while on paid WAPA time, and bypass meters to avoid billing.

locations: St. Thomas, Virgin Islands, United States
keyFacts: Felix Rey, a former WAPA electrician, performed most of the electrical work on Jeffrey Epstein's islands, Little St James and Great St James.

Clinton Hedrington and Felix Rey are accused of 'double-dipping'—using WAPA resources for private jobs and bypassing meters, leading to unbilled energy loss ('Line Loss') passed on to other customers.

The Virgin Islands Department of Planning and Natural Resources (DPNR) is noted as the repository for electrical permits, some of which were allegedly signed off by Hedrington and Rey for their private work.
Edward Bertrand worked for WAPA from 1990 to 2015, holding roles in mapping and as a Staking Engineer, and served as a Hurricane First Responder.
